document.docAuthor: Stadie, Dirk, Fiebig, Ralf & Rajaei, Hossein
document.docTitle: Hydria loebeli Stadie & Fiebig & Rajaei 2022, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic review of the genus Hydria H, 1822 (Lepidoptera, Geometridae, Larentiinae) in the Middle East, with description of three new species and one new subspecies

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic review of the genus Hydria H, 1822 (Lepidoptera, Geometridae, Larentiinae) in the Middle East, with description of three new species and one new subspecies

mods:name.mods:affiliation: State Museum of Natural History Stuttgart, Rosenstein 1, D- 70191 Stuttgart, Germany.

FIGURES 26–30. Male genitalia. Fig. 26:
Hydria cervinalis cervinalis
(Germany, Kaiserstuhl, Badberg, g. prep. 2326/2020 H. Rajaei); Fig. 27:
Hydria cervinalis taurica
subsp. n. , Paratype, (Turkey, prov. Antalya, Civizli W Seydisehir, g. prep. DS- 122/2012); Fig. 28:
Hydria gernoti
sp. n. , Paratype, (Turkey, Nigde, Ala Dagi, g. prep. DS 99/2012); Fig. 29:
Hydria schachti
sp. n. Paratype (Turkey, Ispir, g. prep. DS-112/2012); Fig. 30,
Hydria
(cf.) sp. n., paratype (Azerbaijan, Talysh, Zuvand, g. prep. DS-05/2012); a = genitalia capsule; b = aedeagus.

FIGURES 31–34. Male genitalia. Fig. 31:
Hydria gaudarica
(Spain, Albarracin, g. prep. DS-108/2012); Fig. 32:
Hydria hyrcana
(Iran, Schakuh, g. prep. 1556 H. Rajaei); Fig. 33:
Hydria montivagata montivagata
(Switzerland, Zermatt, g. prep. 2328/2020 H. Rajaei); Fig. 34,
Hydria loebeli
sp. n. , Patatype (Turkey, prov. Erzurum, Umg. Ispir, g. prep. 2321/2020 H. Rajaei). a = genitalia capsule; b = aedeagus; c = juxta.

Hydria cervinalis cervinalis
; Fig. 36:
Hydria gernoti
sp. n. ; Fig. 37:
Hydria hyrcana
; Fig. 38:
Hydria montivagata montivagata
; Fig. 39,
Hydria loebeli
sp. n.

FIGURES 40–47. Female genitalia. Fig. 40:
Hydria cervinalis cervinalis
(Germany, Kaiserstuhl, Badberg, g. prep. 2327/2020 H. Rajaei); Fig. 41:
Hydria cervinalis taurica
subsp. n. , Paratype, (Turkey, prov. Antalya, Civizli W Seydisehir, g. prep. DS- 121/2012); Fig. 42:
Hydria gernoti
sp. n. , Paratype, (Turkey, prov. Nigde, Ala Dagi, g. prep. 2317/2020 H. Rajaei); Fig. 43:

sp. n. Paratype (Georgia, Achaltzych, g. prep. LL 38/2011); Fig. 44.
Hydria gaudarica
(Spain, Albarracin, g. prep. DS-107/2012); Fig. 45:
Hydria hyrcana
, syntype (Iran, Hajiabad, g. prep. 1555 H. Rajaei); Fig. 46:
Hydria montivagata montivagata
(Switzerland, Zermatt, g. prep. 2329/2020 H. Rajaei); Fig. 47,
Hydria loebeli
sp. n. , Patatype (Turkey, prov. Nigde, Aladag, g. prep. DS-175/2012).

Hydria cervinalis cervinalis ;
Fig. 51:

ssp. n. ; Fig. 53–54:

sp. n. ; Fig. 55–56:

sp. n. ; Fig. 57:
Hydria
(cf.) sp. n.; Fig. 58:

sp. n.

FIGURES 63–70. Photos of habitat, larva and adult specimens . Fig. 63.
Hydria cervinalis cervinalis
(ScoPoLI, 1763) female, Germany, Sachsen-Anhalt, Lutherstadt Eisleben, Hüneburg (photo DIRK STaDIE); Fig. 64. Habitat of
Hydria cervinalis cervinalis
(see above): westward facing warm slope with a forest steppe-like mosaic of vegetation with
Prunus spinosa
,
Rhamnus cathartica
,
Crataegus monogyna
,
Berberis communis
and others. At this locality the
Hydria
-species is associated with
Perizoma hydrata
(TREITScHKE, 1829),
Triphosa dubitata
(LInnaEUS, 1758) and
Hadena filograna (ESPER, 1788)
(photo DIRK STaDIE); Fig. 65.
Hydria cervinalis simplonica
WacKERZaPP, 1890 female, Switzerland, Wallis, Zermatt-Balmen, ex larva (photo HEInER ZIEGLER); Fig. 66. Larva of
Hydria cervinalis simplonica
hiding in a silken web between the leaves of
Berberis communis
, Switzerland, Wallis, Zermatt-Balmen, ex larva (photo HEInER ZIEGLER); Fig. 67. Larva of
Hydria cervinalis simplonica
, locality see above, ex larva (photo HEInER ZIEGLER); Fig. 68. Habitat of
Hydria cervinalis simplonica
, warm, rocky escarpment on lime stone, rich in different bushes, Switzerland, Wallis, Rhone valley near Leuk, Feschelbach, 650m (photo HEInER ZIEGLER); Fig. 69. Habitat of
Hydria cervinalis simplonica
, dry and rather open pine forest in the understorey
Berberis communis
, Switzerland, Wallis, Rhone valley, Leuk, Pfynwald, 550–580m (photo HEInER ZIEGLER); Fig. 70.
Hydria gudarica
, L5 larva, Spain Sierra de Guillimona (photo. DIRK STaDIE).

FIGURES 71–77. Photos of habitat and adult specimens. Fig. 71. Col Du Zad, province Khenifra, Morocco. The locality is a habitat of
Hydria gudarica
( DUFaY , 1983) at 2,135m. The habitat is an open Cedar forest mixed with dry, species-rich meadows (photo. noRbERT PöLL ); Fig. 72. Turkey, Middle Taurus, Civizli, type locality of
Hydria cervinalis taurica
ssp. n. during the flight period of the adults in mid-May. The forests in the background are dominated by
Quercus cerris
and
Juniperus excelsa
. At forest clearings
Berberis species
and wild
Pyrus
trees are present (photo DIRK STaDIE ); Fig. 73.
Hydria gernoti
sp.n. male PT, Turkey, Province Nigde, Als dagi, Sulucaova vic., 2,100m, ex ovo (photo DIRK STaDIE ); Figs 74–75. Type locality of
Hydria gernoti
sp. n. in the Ala dagi mountains at 2,300m in mid-May. In foreground right some leafless bushes of
Berberis
(photo DIRK STaDIE , RaLF FIEbIG); Figs 76–77. Habitat of
Hydria loebeli
sp. n. and
H. gernoti
sp. n. , small river valley near Göreme, Central Turkey (photo DIRK STaDIE , RaLF FIEbIG).

FIGURES 78–84. Photos of habitat, larva and adult specimens. Fig. 78.
Hydria montivagata andalusica
, Spain Sierra Nevada (reared) (photo. DIRK STaDIE); Fig. 79. L5-larva of
Hydria montivagata andalusica
, Spain Sierra Nevada ex larva (photo DIRK STaDIE); Fig. 80. Habitat of
Hydria relicta
, a vegetation with a steppic character near the timber line, in fore ground xeromontane steppe with
Protea
-species and several
Ericaceae
(montane Fynbos elements) in the background trees of
Hagenia abyssinica
and
Juniperus procera
at Rutundu fishing lodge (Mount Kenya) at 3,100m (photo PHILIPP STaDIE, RaLF FIEbIG); Figs 81–83. Habitat of
Hydria relicta
, area around Rutundu fishing lodge (montane Fynbos elements) Mount Kenya (photo PHILIPP STaDIE, RaLF FIEbIG); Fig. 84. Host plant
Berberis holstii
of
Hydria relicta
near Rutundu fishing lodge at Mount Kenya (photo Dirk Stadie).

FIGURE 85. Neighbour joining tree shows the relationship between different species of
Hydria (Partim)
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. ( Figs 22–23 ) Wingspan 27–37 mm . Apex of forewing pointed. Ground colour of the wings warm ochre-brown to light ochre (Cappadocia), wavy transverse line darker; the area between postmedial line and subterminal line light-brown. Hindwings light ochre to light ochre-brown; transverse lines indistinct, invisible towards the wing base. Wing surface with a strong lustre. Termen undulating; subterminal line present; terminal line continuously medium brown. Wing underside uniform light brown, on forewing postmedial line only present at the upper two third, absent or very weak towards inner margin. On hindwing underside the postmedial line being usually weaker, sometimes absent. Discal spot hardly visible on forewing, weak or absent on hindwing. Terminal line very thin on both wings. Fringes slightly darker than the ground colour. In male, the patch of androconial hairscales on underside of hindwing dorsum grey-brown, more concentrated towards tornus. High variable in all pattern.

Male genitalia. ( Figs 34 , 39 ) Uncus triangular, apically rounded. Valva membranous, lobe-like, apically rounded. Sacculus projection digitiform, more or less straight, reaching to half of the length of valva, its apex rounded. Juxta trapezoid, distally with two lateral fine projections and an elongated medial bifurcated lobe. Labides well developed, reaching to the mid of uncus, apically thin, clubbed and covered with hairs. Saccus broadly rounded. Aedeagus cylindrical, straight. Vesica covered with tiny dotted microcornuti, apically with a pair of long needleshaped, stout cornuti (sometimes only a single cornutus), basally with a patch of short cornuti.

Female genitalia. ( Fig. 47 ) Ovipositor large, wide. Posterior apophyses three times longer than anterior apophyses. Antrum and lamella antevaginalis membranouse. Ductus bursae wide, short. Corpus bursae largely elongated, with two distinguishable parts: posteriorly well sclerotized, covered with a ridge of tiny spines along the corpus bursae and small patch of spines close to membranous part; anteriorly membranous without any spine.

Diagnosis. Based on its size and wing pattern the new species could be confused only with
H. montivagata
. The background of wings of
H. loebeli
have a warm-brown to light orange hue (grey-brown to grey ochre in
H. montivagata
). The andoconial hairscales on dorsum hindwing of male in
H. loebeli
are grey ochre elongated from basal to tornus of hindwing (dark brown with more concentration towards tornus in
H. montivagata
). On the male genitalia,
H. loebeli
has an uncus with clearly long apical part, apically rounded; juxta short, its apical lobe triangular; vesica with one or two long needle-shaped cornuti at its apical part and a patch of tiny spines an its basal part in
H. loebeli
(uncus short, trapezoid; juxta long, its apical lobe elongated and shallowly bifurcated; the patch of tiny spines at basal part of vesica is absent in
H. montivagata
). In
H. loebeli
the sacculus part of valva clearly longer than in
H. montivagata
(this character is only visible in natural position and will be changed in embedded structure; see Figs 38–39 ). In female genitalia,
H. loebeli
has a less sclerotized ductus bursae; posterior apophyses three times longer than anterior apophyses (ductus bursae strongly sclerotized; posterior apophyses twice longer than anterior apophyses
in montivagata
).

Genetics. Show barcode sharing with both
H. hyrcana
and
H. montivagata
, all three species could be diagnosed based on male and female genitalia (see discussion section).
Distribution. So far only known from Asia Minor ( Turkey ). Occurrence in Armenia and western parts of Azerbaijan is most likely by zoogeographic reasons.

Habitat. The species inhabits a wide range of habitats.
H. loebeli
was recorded in dry xeromontane high mountain steppes, in warm and herb-rich steppes of Inner Anatolia (Cappadocia) and edges and clearings of broadleaved forest of north-east Turkey (prov. Erzurum ) as well ( Fig. 76, 77 ). The hostplant seems to be facilitated by grazing of human livestock.

Phenology. According to the data the imaginal period lasts from mid-May to the end of August. The very early records from mid-May from the Nemrut Dagh (worn specimen!) and Cappadocia indicate the presence of two regular generations in sites with favourable climate, whereas a single brood occurs in cold, high montane and northern areas. This hypothesis could be confirmed by rearing experiments under laboratory conditions ( J . Gelbrecht, pers. communication).

Biology. Life cycle like in the genus description. Hostplants are probably local
Berberis species.
